DOC.HEAD: OAS Weighs Resolution Condeming US Invasion Into Panama

Eds: INSERTS 8th graf: ``Among the,'' to include countries condemning the U.S. action; subs 10th graf, which was 9th graf pvs: ``The OAS,'' to show they did not consider which government they recognized
With AM-US-Panama, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: U.S. allies in Latin America condemned the use of force by the United States in speeches Wednesday before the Organization of American States but bogged down in haggling over procedures to vote on a resolution. Many of the members spoke out against the U.S. attacks in Panama but they held fast to a rule requiring resolutions be submitted 24 hours before a vote can take place. They agreed to meet again Thursday. The resolution was suggested by Panamanian ambassador Jose Maria Cabrera, a supporter of Gen. Manuel Antonio Noreiga, and was introduced by Nicaragua. Cabrera called on the OAS to condemn the ``brutal and criminal aggression'' against his country by the United States. The United States asked members to ``rally around'' the decision to send American troops into Panama. ``We hope you will understand and support our action,'' said U.S. representative Luigi Einaudi. In a separate action, the Mexican government condemned the U.S. invasion, although it also denounced Noriega. ``The fight against international crime is not sufficient reason to intervene in a sovereign nation,'' the Mexican government said in a statement issued through its embassy in Washington. ``In Mexico's opinion, dialogue and negotiation continue to offer the best alternative in finding a peaceful solution to the situation.'' Among the usual allies condemning the use of force at the OAS meeting were Brazil, Chile, Peru, Haiti, Uruguay and Costa Rica. Before the meeting began, the members met behind closed doors to discuss a letter sent by Panama's newly sworn-in president, Guillermo Endara, asking that the OAS recognize Lawrence Chewning Fabrega as his designated representative. The letter was telefaxed from the U.S. Southern Command. The OAS members decided to recognize Cabrera. They did not consider the issue of whether they recognized Endara and his government. ``The forces of the United States continue bombing,'' Cabrera told the OAS ministers at an emergency session called by Panama to denounce the U.S. invasion in his country. ``Under no circumstances will we accept some supposed leaders who are puppets imposed by the United States,'' he said, referring to Endara's government, which is recognized by the Bush administration. The resolution before the OAS asked members to condemn the use of force and demand a withdrawal of the troops. One of the ambassadors, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said shortly before the meeting began that the OAS ``has to condemn this act, no matter how bad Noriega is. We can't condone violence.'' President Bush said Wednesday that he ordered troops into Panama to save American lives and bring Noriega to the United States to be tried on drug trafficking charges. Bush said the United States would withdraw its invasion force as soon as possible. ``The United States is very pleased that the outlaw regime manipulated by Manuel Antonio Noriega has given way to a regime that reflects the democratic will of the people,'' Einaudi told OAS members. ``Noriega increasingly acted in an unstable, unpredictable and dangerous manner.'' The Nicaraguan representative, Victoria Castillo, sided with Panama. ``It is an aberration to speak of democracy and carry out aggression,'' she said.
